messages.text: Is there a way to check for integer overflow on some operations only? I have many decreasing operations that are dafe but some are unsafe, using SaferIntegers everywhere might be to expensive.

Try SaferIntegers -- you are certainly allowed to use it in a limited way.  The only practical matter is that `SafeInts` are strongly attractive -- you need to unsafe any value that you want to use unsafely with an explicit conversion.  And -- it is worth just running your code Safely, there are users who write all of their code with SaferIntegers -- and that code is intensive.  It is easy to start everywhere Safe and then back out of computational regions' safety once you have become confident in their proper logic.  If you have other questions -- ask me.

Hi all, I’m having some trouble with my Julia workflow, and I’d love some recommendations. This question has some Julia and some VSCode components (I’m new to both). Not sure if that’s appropriate for this channel.
First, my compile times are really long, like order of minutes. I’m running some simple training scripts  for Flux in the VSCode Julia REPL, that depend on ~5 small custom modules. I know precompilation is a major focus of the upcoming release, but are there other ways to mitigate this startup time? For instance, is there a way to have VSCode continuously compile my code (this would also maybe help with syntax highlighting)? I’ve tried using Revise, but I found that the state in my repl quickly got confusing, and I ended up just using `include(<script.jl>)`  anyway. In a related point, it looks like maybe there isn’t a way to <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/how-to-clear-variables-and-or-whole-work-space/10149|reset the state of the REPL> without restarting, which then necessitates a recompile. I haven’t really gotten the Debugger to work (it often just hangs), but I didn’t spend much time looking into it. What workflows do you all use?

messages.text:
Second, as I’m learning Julia, I’m having some trouble discovering Julia functionality. Back when I used to code in Java, autocomplete on an object would instantly show me all the available methods. While the language itself was sometimes limited, I was confident I was using all of what was available. In Julia, I’m confident that I’m NOT using all that is available. I know the situation is harder with multiple dispatch, but how do you all learn about functionality quickly?
I think my issues generally fall into two categories. First, basic, stupid questions that I probably missed or forgot the first time I read through the docs. Things like “how do I create a typed array?” took me an inordinately long time to find (`FLoat32[1.0, 2.0]`) when my first guess of `Array{Float32, 1}(1.0, 2.0)` didn’t work. Maybe this is just a failing of my search methods, but what has worked for learning other languages hasn’t worked as well for Julia especially for manipulating arrays and IndexedTables. Second, there seem to be a lot of syntactical tricks that I keep coming across. For instance, `Float32[1.0, 2.0]` creates a 1D array but `Float32[1.0 2.0]` creates a 2D array. How do I discover more of those?

Ah, so I definitely sympathize with this, but also just to share the two things that I have found to be helpful in this regard over time:
1) The built-in help provided by `?` at the REPL is IMO excellent _if you can find the exact name of the thing you need_
2) The `apropos` function can be useful for finding the exact names of a few relevant things, to try `?` on

root.text:
Second, as I’m learning Julia, I’m having some trouble discovering Julia functionality. Back when I used to code in Java, autocomplete on an object would instantly show me all the available methods. While the language itself was sometimes limited, I was confident I was using all of what was available. In Julia, I’m confident that I’m NOT using all that is available. I know the situation is harder with multiple dispatch, but how do you all learn about functionality quickly?
I think my issues generally fall into two categories. First, basic, stupid questions that I probably missed or forgot the first time I read through the docs. Things like “how do I create a typed array?” took me an inordinately long time to find (`FLoat32[1.0, 2.0]`) when my first guess of `Array{Float32, 1}(1.0, 2.0)` didn’t work. Maybe this is just a failing of my search methods, but what has worked for learning other languages hasn’t worked as well for Julia especially for manipulating arrays and IndexedTables. Second, there seem to be a lot of syntactical tricks that I keep coming across. For instance, `Float32[1.0, 2.0]` creates a 1D array but `Float32[1.0 2.0]` creates a 2D array. How do I discover more of those?

messages.text: Does anyone know how to implement a <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Branch_table|jump table> in Julia? There is this issue in Automa.jl: It auto-generates code using `@goto` statements. Sometimes it needs to code in a series of jumps like "first, goto X and execute that block. When done, goto Y, and then Z". The implementation in Automa right now is to *not* jump around multiple times but instead to inline the content of X and Y before a jump to Z. Efficient, but it also can create explosive codegen (since all code blocks can be inlined once for every combination of blocks it can appear in).

attachments.title: Branch table
attachments.text: In computer programming, a branch table or jump table is a method of transferring program control (branching) to another part of a program (or a different program that may have been dynamically loaded) using a table of branch or jump instructions. It is a form of multiway branch. The branch table construction is commonly used when programming in assembly language but may also be generated by compilers, especially when implementing optimized switch statements whose values are densely packed together.

Hello, I am really new with Julia and I wanted to get your advice on backtesting here. I am currently working only with python and is slowly moving part of more computationally intensive work to Julia.

*Problem:*
```Let's say I have a dataset from a csv file of 40million rows of timestamps and share price by ticks (the interval could be by seconds, or even up to minutes during less liquid hours). I would like to backtest with a sliding window of fixed 1 hour for instance. 
Should I be slicing each window from the 40 million dataset, or is there a more efficient way of doing so?```
That was one way I used in Python but it was really slow. Other ideas I could thought of was splitting the dataset into smaller set of files, but that would require writing another function to communicate between the files.
Without trying, I also wouldn’t be able to know the optimal size to split into for improvement in speed. I wanted to know if you have similar experience or advice that could help me?

Thanks!
